newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgium extends Berlaymont bank loan deadline.
newsitem.headline: Belgium extends Berlaymont bank loan deadline.

text.p: The Belgian government on Friday approved an extension of bank loans given to Berlaymont 2000, the company overseeing the renovation of the European Commission's former Brussels headquarters building.

The 5.7 billion Belgian franc loan from Belgian banks Bacob NV and ASLK-CGER, a 49.9 percent owned unit of Belgian-Dutch Fortis, covers part of the cost of removing asbestos from the building and renovating it throughout.
The total cost is estimated at nine billion Belgian francs, a spokeswoman for Belgium's public buildings office told Reuters.

The deadline for the loan was extended to April 30, 1998, from April 30, 1997. It is the second time the duration of the loan has been adjusted. The loan was originally due to expire on April 7, 1995, the spokeswoman said.

"These decisions form part of the plan to renovate the Berlaymont to again house European Commission civil servants in the building at the beginning of the year 2000," the government said in a statement.
